cab.content: Printed for the War Cabinet. May 1940.SECRET. Copy No.W.M. (40)130th Conclusions.TO BE KEPT UNDER LOCK AND KEY.It is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document.WAR CABINET 130 (40).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10 Downing Street.S.W. 1, on Sunday, May 19, 1940, a* 4-30 p.m.Present :The Right Hon. Winston S. Churchill, M.P., Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. Neville Chamberlain,M.P., Lord President of the Council.The Right Hon. Viscount Halifax,Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Right Hon. C. R. Attlee, M.P.,Lord Privy Seal.The Right Hon. A. Greenwood, M.P.,Minister without Portfolio.The following were also present:The Right Hon. A. V. Alexander, j The Right Hon. Anthony Eden, M.P.,M.P., First Lord of the Admiralty, j Secretary of State for War.The Right Hon. Sir Archibald ] The Right Hon. Sir John Anderson,Sinclair, Bt., M.P., Secretary of I M.P., Secretary of State for theHome Department and Minister ofHome Security.The Right Horn A. Duff Cooper, M.P.Minister of Information.State for Air.The Right Hon. Viscount Caldecote,Secretary of State for DominionAffairs.The Hon. Sir Alexander Cadogan, j Air Chief Marshal Sir Cyril L. N.Permanent Under-Secretary of State j Newall, Chief of the Air Staff,for Foreign Affairs.Admiral of the Fleet Sir dudley pound, First Sea Lord and Chief ofNaval Staff.General Sir W. Edmund Ironside,Chief of the Imperial General Staff.Secretariat.Sir Edward Bridges.Major-General H. L. Ismay.Captain A. D. Nicholl, R.N.Lieutenant-Colonel V. Dykes, R.E.[21307b]THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OP HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT WAR CABINET 130 (40).The Western 1 The War Cabinet had under consideration the latestFront. developments in the military situation on the Western Front.Progress of A record of the discussion, and of the Conclusions reached,operations. is contained in the Secretary's Standard File of War Cabinet(Previous Conclusions.Reference:W.M. (40) 129thConclusions,Minute 1.)United States of 2. The Prime Minister read to the War Cabinet the draft of aAmerica. personal message which he proposed to send to President Roosevelt.Personal The War Cabinet signified their approval of the terms ofmessage from draft subject to certain minor amendments.the PrimeMinister toPresidentRoosevelt.(previous references:W.M. (40) 126thConclusions,Minute 9,and 129thConclusions,Minute 8.)Richmond Terrace, S.W. 1.May 19. 1940.
